text:
What i have been trying to do since the divorce filing was reach agreement with you in a way that minimized involvement of 3rd parties, but structure
an agreement that demonstrated the seriousness of what transpired and what needs to happen to move forward to provide safety for all.
After your outburst on Sunday, and continuing demand I file charges, and lack of true accountability, I stepped back and reevaluated the totality of
what transpired in the relationship and your continuing behavior to me. While I have been focused on substance abuse and protecting against that, as
that is what I recognized and was familiar with, the domestic violence aspect experienced by kids and I was truly never acknowledged. I have done
extensive reading on this subject now and how PP should be structured.
I now realize that my approach was wrong, and my initial efforts were actually short sighted, as it did not set up a plan for long term healing and
potential positive outcomes.
I will have my lawyer reach out to yours to provide our thoughts on next steps.
Message 2142 of 4024
Thanks for the amazing period leading up till July 5th. It was magic. I truly felt we were one, and on a trajectory for a happy lifetime as soulmates.
I will always have those magic memories of the best our family ever was, reaching for the stars to achieve even more together, as one happy family.
I’ll always cherish when we knew we finally got it right.
Best wishes my Queen. You were, and forever will be.

Should we chat?
It feels like we’ve veered so far off track that finding our way back seems almost impossible. Our love once blazed as brightly as the stars, but that same
energy now powers a relentless cycle of hate and disdain.
Every week, I suggest trying something new, anything to help us see the good in each other again and build a life our boys would be proud to emulate.
I’ve been pushing for us to keep things civil, and you say you are tired of the endless fighting. Yet, somehow, things keep spiraling every day, with each
of us only seeing perspectives from our POV.
We both know this isn’t working, and no therapist would disagree. What do you say we take a moment, step back from the chaos on the dancefloor,
and look at where we are from the balcony?
Maybe it’s time to consider healthier paths, anything different from the mess we are in now. Every week, we agree this does not work. Every week we
still find common ground. Then every week we abandon that and fight even harder. I'd like to discuss this with a cooler head if you would.
Thanks!
